description: From Middle English foreboden, from Old English forebodian, equivalent to fore- +â€Ž bode.

verbs.description: forebode (third-person singular simple present forebodes, present participle foreboding, simple past and past participle foreboded)

entries.meaning: To predict a future event; to hint at something that will happen (especially as a literary device).
To be prescient of (some ill or misfortune); to have an inward conviction of, as of a calamity which is about to happen; to augur despondingly.
examples: Sullen, desponding, and foreboding nothing but wars and desolation, as the certain consequence of Caesar's death.
